title.narrative: Rohingya Refugee Response March-December 2018

description.narrative: The total Rohingya population in Cox’s Bazar now exceeds 880,000, putting a severe strain on the district’s host community and local government, particularly in Teknaf and Ukhia upazilas, where the Rohingya now constitute at least a third of the total population. On top of existing needs, the upcoming rainy season will increase the riskof disasters such as floods and landslides, but also water contaminationand disease outbreaks. Through this project IOM will provide Site Development, Shelter/Non-Food Items (NFI), water, sanitation and hygiene(WASH), and health activities and other humanitarian assistance to the Rohingya population in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh.

IOM will provide camp coordination and camp management (CCCM) support to an estimated 134,993 individuals at 9 sitesand to 25 organizations and will provide non-food item (NFI) support to an estimated 33,000 individuals.

description.narrative: IOM aims to implement activities in displacement management system (DMS) and Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), and it intends to address the gaps identified by the inter-agency rapid assessment mission on humanitarian needs led by OCHA in February 2018 in Logo, Guma and Makurdi Local Government Authority (LGAs) in Benue State and Awe LGA in Nasarawa State through: Coordination of camp activities and active sectors at eight IDP camps or camp-like settings; Improving site management by further strengthening site management structures and enabling stronger leadership; Enhancing knowledge of site management and mobilization of community committees for National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) and other local stakeholders; as well as provide direct assistance to households in the same locations, through Emergency Shelter kits and Non-Food Item (NFI) kits.

title.narrative: FILOXENIA - Temporary Shelter and Protection for the Most Vulnerable Migrants in Greece

description.narrative: Throughout 2018, Greece continues experiencing an emergency situation related to migration flows and migration management due to the significant number of arrivals, the overstretched accommodation facilities both on the islands and on the mainland and the subsequent protection and safety concerns. Through the present action, IOM will alleviate suffering of vulnerable migrants currently residing under lamentable conditions in Reception and Identification Centers (RICs) by urgently providing dignified accommodation as well as basic assistance and protection services to migrants and refugees residing in accommodation facilities on the mainland, as part of the Government of Greece’s overall emergency planning for the decongestion of the reception facilities on the islands.

These plans incorporate community-development approaches to identify local priorities for the construction or rehabilitation of productive infrastructure, the provision of quick impact livelihoods inputs utilizing ‘cash for work’ approaches, and improved access to markets and farming practices. IOM also conducts multi-sector assessments on conflict, livelihoods, and migration.

description.narrative: The project addresses the last phase of the implementation of the formalization public policy with the management and promotion of the processes for the granting of property titles. This initiative aims to formalize and promote land tenure rights in rural Columbia, with a particular focus on supporting and informing vulnerable populations. Within the framework of the execution of the project and as a transversal axis, a strategy of institutional strengthening and inclusion of the community in solving the problem is proposed through two lines of work: the application of routes to consolidate the legal security of rural lands for the rural population; 2. accompany the territorial entities so that they strengthen their human capital and can have an efficient administrative, technical and financial management in the process management.

title.narrative: Support Reintegration in Conflict-Affected Communities Through an Area-Based Approach

description.narrative: This proposal envisages the establishment of three Community Resource Centres (CRCs) (East Mosul, West Mosul and Fallujah) as part of a wider government-led initiative to support conflict-affected communities. This initiative includes the establishment of CRCs across five governorates affected by significant population displacement and high number of returns, namely Anbar, Diyala, Kirkuk, Ninewa and Salah-al-Din, in cooperation with seven partners, including IOM, under the coordination of an IOM-lead CRC Steering Committee. The CRCs will serve as a hub where community members will be able to find assistance and information on the return and reintegration process, provided by both government on the one hand and humanitarian and development partners, on the other. CRCs will ensure that target community members are well informed as to where to seek specific types of support, as per their individual needs, that they are referred to relevant humanitarian and development partners who provide different services, and that all service delivery is coordinated according to assessed needs.

title.narrative: Promoting Cohesion and Sustainable Community Development in Conflict-Affected Communities in the Donbas

description.narrative: The overall objective of the present action is to contribute towards the Government of Ukraine’s efforts to support socio-economic recovery through the promotion of inclusive, cohesive and stabilized communities affected by conflict in the Donbas region (GCA). IOM’s social cohesion programming envisages the selection of conflict-affected communities hosting a large number of Internal Displaced Populations (IDPs), returnees, former participants of military action, with limited public and administrative services and existing social tensions. As a part of a holistic approach, the present action will be a part of a larger portfolio of activities aimed at building social cohesion through: empowerment of the local communities to hold inclusive events and activities that promote understanding between the host communities, minorities, IDPs and other socially vulnerable groups; support increased communication for host community members and IDPs to jointly address common challenges; and promotion of tolerance for cultural, racial and ethnic diversity in Ukraine to mitigate possible tensions; and provision of additional opportunities for women and promotion of equal opportunities for people with disabilities to strengthen the principles of inclusion.

title.narrative: Strengthening Food Security and Resilience for Conflict-Affected Communities in Yemen

description.narrative: The project contributes to restoring lost or affected livelihoods and enhancing the food security of IDPs and conflict affected populations in the governorates of Abyan, Al Jawf, Shabwa, and Lahj (Yemen) In order to do so, IOM will contribute to restoring lost or affected livelihoods of conflict affected populations in the governorates of Abyan, Al Jawf, Lahj, and Shabwa through provision of solar-powered irrigation systems and agricultural kits, therefore, reducing the impact of agriculture economic losses, and contributing to sustainable livelihoods of farmers and families who engage in agriculture. Moreover, IOM will aim at mitigating the impact of high food prices on IDP populations and enhancing access to food supplies for most vulnerable IDP HHs in the governorates of Abyan and Al Jawf governorates.

description.narrative: This project aims to improve access to basic (education) services for returnees, host communities and Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Lahj governorate, an area facing one of the highest return rates in Yemen. By bringing host communities, IDPs and returnees together in cooperation with local government institutions, this initiative will enhance the social cohesion within the community and support the provision of education services and facilities in areas that were identified by the communities and authorities as most in need. As part of the community stabilization initiative, this project targets four schools in 3 different districts in Lahj Governorate namely: Tuban, Al-Hota and Al-Muasimer districts, in need of rehabilitation, reconstruction, furniture and equipment.

title.narrative: Identifying Government Policies Conducive to Operationalising the Humanitarian Development Nexus (HDN)

description.narrative: This project seeks to set baseline actions to help assess and frame IOM’s approach and policy guidance to operationalizing the Humanitarian Development and Peace Nexus (HDN/HDPN). The HDN/HDPN effort within IOM affords the Organization an opportunity to (i) improve the coherence of its work, in terms of reducing humanitarian need, addressing the longer-term dimensions of crisis and displacement, and promoting earlier and more lasting solutions to displacement; (ii) put forward this experience with key partners and stakeholders as part of the Organization’s commitments to improve upon the HDN/HDPN, and in support of efforts made by partners to engage the development community in earlier and more meaningful interventions in fragile and crisis-affected contexts; and (iii) to empower the work of the Organization, and improve the efficiency of its response, by advancing its humanitarian relief as well as its development assistance toward the Agenda for Humanity and the goals of the Grand Bargain, specifically promoting the New Way of Working.

title.narrative: Emergency Assistance to Conflict Affected Populations in Cameroon: Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM)

description.narrative: The proposed action aims to strengthen the European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO)-funded Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) exercise to better inform humanitarian interventions carried out by governmental and humanitarian partners. The Displacement Tracking Matrix will continue to provide vital information in order to bring efficient and effective provision of humanitarian assistance to conflict-affected populations. Moreover, IOM aims to enlarge the spectrum of data it is collecting in order to allow the publication of more specific information with regard to displaced populations needs. In 2018, the goal is to offer a more action-oriented information on the displaced populations. To do so, IOM will improve the existing reports and material it publishes through the DTM and add new elements to the already existing ones: Site Profiling tool, Events Tracking and ad hoc Flash Products. Those will be designed in accordance to the humanitarian community's inputs and the technical limitations inherent to the DTM.

title.narrative: Strengthening the humanitarian response to conflict-affected populations in north-east Nigeria

description.narrative: There are an estimated 7 million people in need of assistance in Nigeria(OCHA), including approximately 1.9 million displaced by the insurgency (IOM DTM round IX) which started in late 2014. 92% of the IDPs are hosted by under-served host communities, bringing already stretched services and resources under increased pressure. The armed conflict directly affected four states in the North East: Adamawa, Borno, Gombe, and Yobe States. The current humanitarian response covers all four states directly affected, with Borno State being the epi-centre of military operations and displacement of civilians. However, the responseis significantly hampered by very limited funding to meet such large needs, the challenges of response actors to scale up in the affected areas with qualified personnel with emergency profiles and the delays inthe recognition of the Boko Haram crisis as a humanitarian crisis beyondnational capacity. Two years into the crisis some progress has been achieved, but with only 69%of people being reached, the response needs to be scaled up, building on the access, partnerships and field presenceand activities put in place.

title.narrative: Enhancing regional convergence of data collection, analysis and dissemination through the displacement tracking matrix (DTM)

description.narrative: The proposed project aims to enhance regional convergence of data collection, analysis and dissemination through the implementation of three interconnected pillars of activities: I) to undertake in-depth studies on factors shaping different groups of migrants’ decisions to leave their country and chose a route and destination, with a particular focus on forced mobility (year 1) and II) to coordinate and strengthen cross-country and cross-regional data collection and data analysis which links information about mobility patterns with findings regarding the underlying factors that shape migration decisions, seeking to link debates on forced, irregular and regular migration, as well as making the connection between internal and cross-border mobility dynamics, with a strong gender component (year 1-3), and III) to strengthen IOM’s cooperation with OCHA-Hoxton further enhance data interoperability and information sharing mechanisms (year 1-3). This stands to contribute to a fuller and more comprehensive understanding of human mobility patterns that can inform operational actors as well as policy makers and academia on required actions to address and mitigate root causes and to enhance avenues for migration that mutually benefits migrants and society. The project will build upon commitments by other donors, most notably DFID, which is supporting IOM activities to foster a greater understanding of migration flows in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Syria, Turkey, and along the Western Balkans and Mediterranean route, and is initiating a new project to support the establishment of flow monitoring points in Western and Central Africa.

description.narrative: The project aims to save lives and contribute to the protection of IDPs in Ethiopia. The project aims to protect and provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to IDPs through: 1) Accurate and timely displacement data, collected and disseminated to humanitarian partners to support the well-informed coordination, multi-sector rapid response and protection of disaster affected people; 2) Most vulnerable displaced individuals received life-saving Shelter, NFI and dignity kit assistance; 3) Information sharing and reporting strengthened in collaboration with the Protection Cluster and CP/GBV Sub-Clusters to address protection needs of most vulnerable IDPs.

participating-org.narrative: European Commission - Humanitarian Aid & Civil Protection

title.narrative: Strengthening the Implementation and Expansion of Displacement Tracking Activities and Facilitating the Establishment of Humanitarian Hubs in North-Eastern Nigeria

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM aims to continue to increase its emergency response capacity to better serve the humanitarian community in addressing the needs of the most vulnerable populations in North-East Nigeria. In order to do so, IOM's biometric registration expanded its target and included all affected population in the registration so the humanitarian community have been having more up-to-date data on the needs in the most-affected states of North-East Nigeria. Moreover, in order to expand the reach of life-saving activities that the humanitarian community is currently providing to the affected population, IOM is currently working on the establishment of the humanitarian hubs to provide support to the humanitarian community in order to address the short, mid and longer-term needs of IDPs and returnees of over 1 million affected people.

title.narrative: Capacity building of Nepal's national security forces in camp coordination and camp management (CCCM)

description.narrative: Through the present project, IOM aims to contribute to the Government ofNepal's efforts in disaster preparedness through increasing capacity of first responders to effectively manage displaced populations in line with international standards and best practices. A comprehensive response in camp management aims at improving the quality of life and dignity of affected populations during displacement through engagement in participatory processes, working together with, and advocating on behalf of, internally displaced people, as well as other persons affected by humanitarian crisis. The National Red Cross Society (NRCS), as one of the key local responders in Nepal, will also participate in the capacity building activities to bridge the gap between immediate response and longer term management of displaced populations provided byinternational, national and local stakeholders. The proposed action willbe implemented over a two-year period and in close coordination with Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA), Ministry of Defense (MoD), Ministry of Urban Development (MoUD), Department of Urban Development and Building Codes (DUDBC), NA, NP, APF, NRCS and their regional and district offices, and with the support of IOM's Global Camp Coordination and CampManagement (CCCM) Cluster team.

title.narrative: Supporting refugees and migrants through a consolidated Mediterranean and flow-monitoring response in Turkey

description.narrative: Through this project IOM will provide humanitarian assistance to refugees and migrants rescued at sea and continue to operationalize IOM’s Migrant Presence Monitoring (MPM) program, a displacement monitoring and reporting system which provides a regular overview and update on the flows, locations, and vulnerabilities of migrants and refugees in Turkey. The delivery of humanitarian assistance will be focused on the provision of food items, non-food items (NFIs), counselling including psycho-social support (PSS), and referrals to protection services for migrants and refugees rescued at sea (border zone between Turkey and Greece) - more specifically along the coastal area between Küçükkuyu and Bodrum.

Through this project, IOM aims to contribute to addressing the humanitarian and early recovery needs of the most vulnerable persons affected by conflict in eastern Ukraine through: 1. Distribution of coal and cast-iron stoves for the most vulnerable households to meet their heating needs for the upcoming winter; 2. Shelter and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) rehabilitations in social institutions and key community sites; and 3. Pilot livelihood support in the selected areas witnessing a major flow of returnees.

IOM will continue to maintain its presence in the recognized displacement sites in North-Kivu and will extend site management services to the new spontaneous displacement sites in North-Kivu, Tanganyika and Ituri; 3. The most vulnerable IDPs in displacement sites, host communities and return areas will be targeted for the provision of emergency assistance in the Shelter, NFI and WASH sectors; 4. Ensure the protection of those affected by the crisis and avoid forced relocation and/or secondary displacement, IOM will reinforce community-based protection networks in displacement sites and provide tailored assistance to survivors of Gender Based Violence (GBV), victims of trafficking and to the most vulnerable IDPs at risk of exploitation and/or abuse.

title.narrative: Strengthening Emergency WASH Response for Refugees and Host Communities in Palorinya and Kyaka Ii Settlements

description.narrative: Lack of access to safe water and adequate hygiene and sanitation facilities can lead to the rapid propagation of diseases. Nine cases of cholera were reported in Kyaka II on 29 January 2018, eight of whom were among the new arrivals. The need to stabilize access to safe water through adequate water systems, improve sanitation at household level and institutions, expand health and hygiene education and increase the number of hygiene promoters in the two settlements and nearby host communities is dire. Through this project, IOM in Uganda will provide life-saving, sustainable access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene services to South Sudanese and Congolese refugees in Palorinya and Kyaka II settlements and their host communities in Moyo and Kyegegwa districts respectively.

description.narrative: This project will strengthen national and cross-border protection mechanisms and provide humanitarian protection assistance for vulnerable undocumented Afghans returning from Iran and Pakistan through the four major border crossings. Through this project, IOM will strengthen gender-sensitive screening, identification and referrals for Persons with Specific Needs through capacity building for staff, government and protection actors resulting in increased referrals in Afghanistan. Further, IOM will also enhance the humanitarian returnee response to strategically prevent and respond to protection concerns such as trafficking in crisis and gender-based violence for highly vulnerable Afghans. IOM will also establish an Accountability to Affected Populations Feedback Mechanism for the overall humanitarian returnee response.

In order to do so, IOM will work at reducing the vulnerability of undocumented Afghan returnees from Iran through protection-sensitive humanitarian post arrival assistance. The primary aim of this project will be to reduce the vulnerability of Persons with Specific Needs (PSN) through protection-sensitive post-arrival humanitarian assistance, targeted Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS), tailored protection packages including case management, in-kind assistance, cash grants for Non-Food Items (NFIs) and transportation, referrals to protective services and enhanced protection-specific data on mobility patterns for vulnerable groups.

Activities include the provision of individual counselling, screening for vulnerabilities, medical pre-departure medical screening and fit to travel assessments on all refugees requesting assistance to return home and providing referrals and transportation assistance to any migrant in need of higher level care. Building on IOM’s solid in-country emergency and post-crisis experience and being one of the leading responders in the area, IOM will operate through a multisectoral approach, incorporating Site Management Support (SMS), Health, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Shelter/Non-Food Items (Shelter/NFI) support, complemented by IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM).

title.narrative: Common Transport Services for Humanitarian Partners in South Sudan

description.narrative: The Common Transport Services (CTS) is a free-for-user service that transports key humanitarian supplies on behalf of humanitarian actors. CTS serves as a critical link in the supply chain, enabling products and materials that arrive from regional and international suppliers to rapidly move onwards to partners located remotely in the field. Through this project, IOM aims to the effective management of the CTS by supporting humanitarian organizations’ preparedness measures to mitigate risk associated with increased insecurity, looting/theft of humanitarian supplies and critical access impediments to very vulnerable people; reduce expensive air and road transport costs; and ultimately support the timely humanitarian response to the needs of the affected populations.

title.narrative: Promoting Reduction of and Improved Operational Response to Gender-based Violence through Camp Management and Site Planning

description.narrative: Since 2015, IOM has been implementing gender-based violence (GBV) prevention and mitigation activities under the Safe from the Start Initiative supported by US Population Refugees & Migration (PRM). The three-phase project “Promoting the Reduction of and Improved OperationalResponse to Gender-Based Violence through Camp Management and Site Planning has allowed IOM to advance commitments made to the global “Callto Action on Protection from GBV in Emergencies” and develop innovative,operational, context-adaptable tools and approaches to mainstream GBV risk mitigation and prevention into IOM’s three core operational emergency response sectors- Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) and Shelter. The overall objectives of Phase IV are to pursue and deepen the integration of GBV mainstreaming into CCCM and Shelter emergency response, at both agency and sectoral levels, to ensure more systematic and predictable actions to address GBV risks in displacement and promote effective and accountable inter-agency Protection from Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA) leadership and coordination at all levels of the humanitarian architecture.

description.narrative: IOM will contribute to ensuring an adequate humanitarian and recovery response to the needs of the internally displaced, host communities and returnees in North-Eastern Nigeria. In particular, IOM will seek to contribute to the improvement of protection and living conditions of displaced and conflict-affected populations in North-East Nigeria. This will be achieved by: (1) Provision of Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS); (2) The Implementation of Rapid Assessments through the Emergency Tracking Tool (ETT) and Village Assessment Survey Activities; (3) The strengthening of Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) Activities; (4) The Implementation of Critical Shelter Solutions and provision of direct assistance through the distribution of Non-Food Items (NFI).

title.narrative: Water, and Sanitation Hygiene (WASH) Support to the Displaced Rohingya Population in Ukhiya and Teknaf Upazilas, Cox’s Bazar District

description.narrative: The unprecedented number of Rohingya refugees arriving in Cox’s Bazar since August 2017 overwhelmed already weak service-delivery systems which were and remain unable to effectively serve Bangladeshi host communities, let alone the Rohingya refugee population. Despite the efforts made by Government and humanitarian actors to provide water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) services since the influx, the needs in the sector remain considerable to support the 1.3 million people affected by the crisis. Overall, through this UNICEF-IOM joint programme225,316 (female 117,164, male 108,152) people will gain access to safe water and sanitation services, while adopting improved individual and collective health seeking behaviours to mitigate public health risks. Through this project, IOM will provide basic life-saving WASH services in Kutupalong-Balukhali Extension Sites, Camp 9, 10, 11, 13 and 18.

description.narrative: Colombia and Venezuela share a border of 2,219 kilometers the longest frontier Colombia has with its neighbours. For five decades the internalarmed conflict forced the displacement of thousands of victims to other countries, many towards Venezuela. The project goal is to provide integrated humanitarian assistance, legal orientation, and integration activities to persons in need of international protection (PNIP) and members of the receptor communities. This will be accomplished through food and non-food items, school kits, temporary shelter and medical brigades, as well as institutional strengthening for a better assistanceto PNIP in health and legal support, improvement of water and sanitationfacilities, improvement of education facilities and integration activities in benefit of Colombian migrants and Venezuelan communities.

This will be achieved by: 1) Improving the capacity for identification, registration, direct protection and assistance provision, as well as referrals to basic services, such as health care, psychosocial support, education for children, and support for assisted voluntary return; 2) Ensuring adequate shelter and protection-sensitive accommodation non-food items and water, sanitation and hygiene (for Persons of Concern, including those in vulnerable situations; 3) Ensuring access to sufficient food and nutrition, including adequate nutrition for children below 2 years of age; and 4) Strengthening capacity of border control and surveillance, thereby also contributing to the fight against and prevention of migrant smuggling, trafficking in human beings and other types of cross-border crime.

title.narrative: Provision of Humanitarian Assistance to Drought Affected, Displaced and Vulnerable Somalis

description.narrative: In response to the persistent and increasing humanitarian needs, IOM implements a multi-sector humanitarian response in the areas of Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM), health, nutrition and, water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) to strengthen and scale up existing life-saving humanitarian assistance. Activities will target large displacement sites in the country that havebeen receiving significant influx since the onset of the 2017 drought. CCCM and DTM activities complement the overall response by providing accurate and up to date data to inform response and coordinate humanitarian partners to facilitate a holistic and practical response inareas of high displacement. CCCM, health and WASH project activities will be provided in a holistic approach to support to communities susceptible to cholera and wherein public health concerns are exacerbated by overcrowded living conditions. The proposed project is inline with three out of the four key strategic objectives outlined in theSomalia Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) which includes: 1. Provision oflife-saving assistance; 2. Reducing acute malnutrition; and, 3. Reinforcing provision of protection services to affected communities.

This Action will consist of activities falling under five results: 1) Strengthened DRM capacity of Host Communities; 2) Strengthened DRM capacity of community and camp volunteers; 3) Risk-informed upgrading of shelters and reinforcement of community-level structures; 4) Small scale site development and mitigation works and large scale (cut and fill) earthworks in unoccupied zones to increase useable area and reduce the risk of landslide; and 5) Technical capacity is in place to advise humanitarian actors on disaster risk management within the local context.

title.narrative: Displacement Tracking to Vulnerable Migrants, IDPs and Returnees in Yemen

description.narrative: This project, carried out through the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) systems, will consist of the collection, analysis and dissemination of new and pre-existing data on internal displacements and migrant mobility in Yemen to better understand displacement and movement trends, migrants' profiles and needs amongst the mobile vulnerable groups. The objective of this project is to provide a stronger evidence base for humanitarian response, development planning and operations with a comprehensive countrywide analysis generated through the collection of primary data at community level in all the 22 governorates of Yemen. To achieve this objective, IOM aims to collect primary data using baseline assessments (for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and returnees) and flow monitoring (FM) as DTM methodologies. Further, the field teams deployed create a network of key Informants who provides information on the existence of the IDPs and migrants in respective areas. This project will follow a harmonized approach to map and monitor migration trajectories, demographics, associated needs and problems. Data collected will be used to produce regular updates on cross-border and transit mobility, including monitoring trends and movements over time. Data and reports will contribute to a comprehensive analysis of migration flows at the sub-regional level for the counties of Yemen, Djibouti, Somalia and Ethiopia.

title.narrative: Strengthening Assistance to Returnees, IDPs and Mobile Populations in Afghanistan Through the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM)

description.narrative: The overall goal of this project is to contribute to the social cohesion and stabilisation of Afghan communities affected by displacement, return and chronic poverty. The project will use an evidence-based approach, through Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM), to identify locations with high concentrations of returnee, internally displaced and migrant populations. In order to establish a complete national evidence base to inform and strengthen policies, programming and selection of priority areas of intervention for humanitarian, reintegration and development partners, the proposed project aims to expand and enhance DTM’s existing evidence base by implementing settlement-level Baseline Mobility Assessments and Community-based Needs Assessments in thirteen previously unassessed provinces to capture locations, population sizes, mobility trends and multi-sectoral needs of returnees, IDPs, migrants and host communities. The DTM information will enable IOM and its partners to understand the mobility patterns and needs of IDPs, returnees, migrants and host communities, strengthening their ability to deliver mobility-sensitive, better-targeted, sustainable humanitarian assistance, reintegration, and community stabilisation programming.

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM aims at increasing food security throughout South Sudan by supporting effective and efficient food assistance resource allocation and distribution. This project enables IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) to establish biometric authentication stations at the World Food Programme (WFP) food distribution sites, and conduct routine biometric maintenance, as well as additional biometric registrations and verification exercises in order to drive more targeted food distribution, maximize operational impact and support more effective and efficient resource mobilization, whilst strengthening partnership between the two organizations for the benefit of the wider humanitarian community.

title.narrative: Comprehensive Response for the Volcan de Fuego Emergency

description.narrative: IOM plans to support the Government of Guatemala through a people-centred approach that considers diverse age/gender needs. This initiative will be a part of inter-agency shelter coordination, to support local sectoral learning and identification of best practices, deficient at this stage, and will focus on these main areas: 1. Officialregistration of individuals in collective centres: Develop and establishan integrated registration system to provide registration for identification, family reunification, humanitarian assistance, and security purposes; 2. Data collection through the DTM system to support humanitarian assistance and coordination: Tracking numbers of people by age/sex and identifying the critical needs within the clusters structures to improve humanitarian aid and plan for stabilization and reintegration; and 3. Upgrade shelters and sites for comprehensive and integrated management, improvement, and logistics in collective centres.Improve site and shelter management by conducting shelter assessments and planning, organizing and managing teams, delivering assistance, and improving existing or building new infrastructure, based on data collected and assessments conducted through this project.

title.narrative: Displacement and emergency tracking in Burundi

description.narrative: The general objective of this project is to assist the Government of Burundi, in partnership with humanitarian agencies, to access a comprehensive system of information on the presence of internally displaced persons in the country, the needs of this vulnerable population, and emergency events occurring within the country in order to provide timely assistance. In order to do so, this proposed project aims to address the current gaps in humanitarian emergency response in Burundi by: (1) expanding current data collection capacity on internally displaced persons (IDPs) using the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) and (2) creating an Emergency Event Tracking system for rapid assessment following natural disasters and other displacement events.

title.narrative: Support the Strengthening of the Protection Environment for People Displaced from Venezuela to Brazil and Colombia, as a Key Contribution to Preventing Instability, Increasing Resilience and Building National Crisis Response Capacity

description.narrative: This project seeks to enhance the capacity of national, local governmentand civil society organizations (CSOs) to face current and possible future crisis, namely by ensuring sufficient access to trainings, response mechanisms and basic management tools. IOM will do so by: (1)improving protection process and documentation of Venezuelans and returning nationals through enhanced access to relevant information and/or to registration; (2) Contribute to have Community response systems in place, public attitude towards persons of concern is improved, co-existence promoted, and basic services for persons with specific needs are met. IOM will also strengthen the capacity of the Government responses and effective coordination with international and national humanitarian actors ensured to support Venezuelans. Further, risk of forced recruitment of children and Gender Based Violence (GBV) will be reduced and quality of response will be enhanced through this project.

title.narrative: Regional Evidence for Migration Analysis and Policy (REMAP) - Asia and the Middle East

description.narrative: The overall objective of the Action is to strengthen evidence-based formulation and implementation of humanitarian and development policy and programming on migration and forced displacement in Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Iran, Iraq, and Pakistan. In particular, IOM will contributeby gathering, analysing and sharing data on relevant topics to inform and strengthen policy and programming. This will include insight into reintegration challenges and efforts, return intentions and host/return community perceptions in relevant locations, supporting government, humanitarian, and development stakeholders (including relevant departments within IOM) to design, implement and adapt well-evidenced programming to foster resilience and self-reliance. IOM will also aim toincrease the availability and quality of information on the locations, numbers, needs and vulnerabilities of these groups, and by responsible sharing of this information with organizations and government institutions mandated and able to assist these groups and individuals.

title.narrative: Information Tracking and Monitoring for South Sudan Displacement Dynamics

description.narrative: With the overall objective of contributing to an enhanced understanding of mobility dynamics in South Sudan. IOM will continue to capture information on mobility trends and ensure the provision displacement-related data in order to ensure that humanitarian actors are positioned to plan timely and targeted interventions based on a solid evidence base. Under this project, IOM will maintain the largest displacement tracking and monitoring mechanism in the country: the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM). In order to do so, IOM will employ four interlinked and manually reinforcing tools and methodologies, namely: 1) flow monitoring, 2) intention surveys, 3) mobility tracking and 4) biometric registrations.

title.narrative: Protracted Displacement: Defining Priority Needs and Identifying Populations at Risk, and Advancing Durable Solutions

description.narrative: To enable a better and more specific understanding of the location and conditions of protracted internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, through this project, IOM aims to further define and profile the characteristics and geographic distribution of IDPs in a situation of orat risk of protracted displacement in the country. The project will result in (1) a tool that will provide the baseline for further action; (2) targeted research aiming to provide in-depth profiles and information about specific groups of people in protracted displacement; and (3) further data for enhanced targeting, strategy development and advocacy on behalf of these vulnerable populations. The information gathered through this project will allow stakeholders to deliver tailored, evidence-based solutions that address specific immediate and medium-term needs and enable the government and international community to advocate for these at-risk populations.

title.narrative: Support Cluster Response to Drought-Affected Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), through Monitoring IDPs Inflow and Outflow, as well as Intention Survey, in Herat and Badghis

description.narrative: In response to critical levels of internal displacement in Afghanistan caused by what is being described as the worst drought in the country indecades, through this action IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) will continue to implement flow monitoring to identify and register the newly arriving drought-affected internally displaced persons (IDP) caseload in Herat City, as well as in Qala-e-Naw in Badghis. In addition, IOM will share the information with humanitarian partners to facilitate onward registration of newly arriving IDPs into humanitarian assistance programmes and expedite subsequent delivery of assistance. Additionally, DTM will also continue to track the outflow of IDPs returning to their places of origin or into secondary displacement as well as conduct return intention surveys in locations of displacement toidentify the intentions, motivations, needs and concerns. This will enable partners to better integrate the concerns and requirements of potential returnees into return packages and into return strategies in areas of origin to deliver sustainable return solutions.

title.narrative: Capacity Building Support to the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) Towards Protection of Mobile and Fragile Populations in the Philippines

description.narrative: In its efforts to manage and promote safe and orderly migration, the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) is the co-lead of the Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) cluster in natural disasters at the global-level. IOM is also an active member of the Shelter Cluster and has taken a leading role in numerous humanitarian shelter programs in the Philippines and across the world. As the co-leadfor CCCM in the Philippines, and as a leading contributor to the shelterresponses for Typhoon Haiyan and the Marawi Crisis, IOM aims to strengthen the CCCM, shelter and displacement tracking capacity of the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) at the National, Regional and Field Office levels. This will help the government prepare for and respond effectively to humanitarian crises with strong technicalcapacity, coordination and accountability. In order to do so, IOM will strengthen the DSWD's CCCM and Shelter response capacity through training of camp managers from national to local levels and the development of a shelter strategy.

title.narrative: Reintegration and prevention of recruitment programme

description.narrative: The Recruitment Prevention and Reintegration (RPR) program supports the Government of Colombia to prepare for and launch a large-scale reintegration process, make available reintegration services throughout the Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration (DDR) cycle to minimize recidivism, and prevent recruitment of children and youth. IOM will help prepare for large-scale reintegration, improve management and exchange of information, and implement early reintegration activities from the start of the DDR cycle. IOM also aims to increase effectiveness, monitoring and evaluation of current GOC prevention efforts as well as to involve the private sector and civil society and support the GOC to implement the Legal Framework for Peace in connection with legal processing and ex-combatant contributions to truth, reparations and reconciliation.

The objective of the project will be to increase opportunities for economic inclusion in digital ecosystems for adolescents and young people, at risk of linking to new forms of urban violence. In order to do so, IOM, COLOMBIA TELECOMMUNICATIONS and Fundación Telefónica have joined forces to implement the programme, which offers training and career pathways within IT and related fields in order to promote the integration of youth into the growing digital workforce and provide an alternative to involvement in urban violence.

title.narrative: Demobilization, Disassociation, Reintegration and Reconciliation: Conflict Dissolution and Peacebuilding in Nigeria

description.narrative: In this project, the Demobilization and Disassociation, Reintegration and Reconciliation (DDRR) programme will support the Government of Nigeria in its efforts to create legal, policy and operational frameworks which facilitate positive ‘off-ramping’ options for individuals seeking to separate from Boko Haram and ISIS West Africa (BH/ISIS-WA). Another key element of the DDRR program is to assist the Government of Nigeria in forming a successful reintegration process for individuals currently detained in civilian centres or who remain within military custody, but who will eventually return to conflict-affected communities. A final component of the program is integrating social reconciliation efforts in conflict-affected communities.

title.narrative: Demobilization, Disassociation, Reintegration And Reconciliation: Conflict Resolution and Peacebuilding in the Lake Chad Region (Cameroon, Chad and Niger)

description.narrative: This regional project will operationalize a Demobilization and Disassociation, Reintegration and Reconciliation (DDRR) program for Boko Haram fighters, associates and victims, including those caught up in related security operations. It will do so through a four pronged approach: assessment, context analysis and national planning, upstream government support, individual case management and community based reintegration and reconciliation. IOM’s proposed DDRR approach for the Lake Chad Region for this specific project will geographically focus on Chad, Cameroon and Niger. It will integrate the various elements of the protection, prevention, stabilization, transition and peacebuilding equation to create nationally-tailored, positive ‘off-ramping’ options for individuals who have separated from Boko Haram, along with community reintegration and reconciliation mechanisms, as a critical step for regional peacebuilding and restoration of social cohesion.

Likewise, the project aims to assist youth identified at community levelas being vulnerable to or at risk of recruitment into such groups, whilealso improving the absorptive capacities of local businesses as a means of promoting economic and social stabilisation in the target communities. This project is the fourth extension of the activities undertaken by IOM under the PHSS framework since 2015.

title.narrative: Strengthening Provision of Rehabilitation Services for Former Boko Haram Associates in Gombe Transition Centre in North-East Nigeria

description.narrative: The proposed project will focus on capacity building and individual casemanagement at the government-led transition centre in Gombe State, North-East Nigeria. Individuals participating in the rehabilitation programme commit to separate from the Boko Haram movement and ideology, get away from any kind of criminal activities, and return to the community and engage in exemplar civilian life. The 16-week programme focuses on spiritual and ideological counselling, de-radicalisation, psychosocial support, drug abuse prevention, sports, skills acquisition and vocational training. In particular, the project will improve basic health care for the participants, ensuring they are medically fit to return to communities upon graduation from the larger rehabilitation programme.

title.narrative: Improving Legal Assistance to Migrants in Brazil and Promoting their Access to Labour Markets

description.narrative: Migration flows to and from Brazil have profoundly changed over the past ten years, creating new challenges for the protection of migrants’ rights and access to labor markets. Although a new migration law was adopted and now incorporates the main standards and principles of international law, Brazil still lacks structured public policies to facilitate the integration of migrants. This project will contribute to fostering migrant integration in Brazil by strengthening the capacity of the Federal Public Attorney staff and enhancing legal assistance to migrants. An online course and training of trainers’ workshop aims to build the knowledge of civil servants and public attorneys with regard to the protection of migrants’ rights, in particular those of women and irregular migrants. Furthermore, an analysis of corporate policies for migrants to access the Brazilian labor market will be carried out by the United Nations Global Compact Network partners. This analysis will review the main legal gaps preventing migrants from working for companies that are members of the UN Global Compact Network in Brazil. Finally, the UN Global Compact Network companies will take part in a workshop to acquire skills and tools to design and adopt innovative corporate social responsibility policies that focus on strengthening migrant integration, with special provision for women.

title.narrative: E-Learning Solutions to Support the Justice Academy of the Ministry of Justice of Azerbaijan – Phase II

description.narrative: This project supports the Justice Sector Reforms in Azerbaijan by building the capacity of the Justice Academy to provide trainings, develop and institutionalize courses within the formal curriculum of theAcademy. The project aims to contribute to the Academy's efforts to build capacity of, judges, candidate judges, prosecutors and lawyers. Inaddition, the project aims to expand access to justice as it anticipatesestablishment of Legal Aid Centers and provision of pro-bono legal aid in four regional hubs. The proposed activities are the extension of the E-Learning Solutions to Support Justice Academy of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Azerbaijan project and aim to further enhancecapacities and learning at the judicial level. The proposed extension has been designed and will be carried out in close coordination and cooperation with the Academy as a result of the project's successful implementation capacities of justice sector actors addressing domestic and transnational crimes will be improved. Additionally the project withfurther contribute to the implementation of national action plans pertaining to criminal justice reforms in the country. Furthermore, the action will contribute to the civil society participation through facilitation of engagement in the provision of free legal aid to the population and consequently expand access to justice in the country.

title.narrative: Promoting Psychosocial Services and Assistance for Vulnerable Migrants in Morocco

description.narrative: Morocco is a transit corridor for migrants wishing to reach Europe and in recent years increasingly also a destination country. According to the Moroccan Ministry of Interior 25,000 to 40,000 irregular migrants, originating mostly from Western Sub-Saharan Africa, reside in Morocco. Despite recent governmental efforts to develop a comprehensive human -rights based approach migration policy, which included an exceptional regularization, many migrants, often in an irregular situation, find themselves stranded and in a situation of vulnerability facing harsh living conditions and a lack of resources to survive. As highlighted in a recent study conducted in Morocco, despite efforts by various governmental and non-governmental actors, access to health services for irregular migrants remains difficult although their precarious living conditions as well as the violence they face on a fairly basis means they have unmet psychosocial and medical needs. This is why, IOM proposes to contribute to improve psychosocial support services to migrants in Morocco through a two-fold action based on capacity-buildingactivities for medical professionals in Morocco and on direct service provision to enhance pre-departure services offered to migrants in the context of the Assisted Voluntary Return and Reintegration (AVRR) programme.

title.narrative: Middle East HIV, Tuberculosis and Malaria Response

description.narrative: The Middle East Response (MER) initiative is an innovative approach thatwill provide essential HIV, TB, and malaria services to eligible countrypopulations in Syria, Yemen and Syrian refugees in Jordan and Lebanon. This will be done through one regional grant management platform with the aim of improving responsiveness to the three diseases in the contextof emergencies in the aforementioned countries. The grant will consolidate current national grants in Syria, Yemen and the Emergency Fund Grant in Jordan and Lebanon. The scope of interventions under the grant was tailored to reflect the protracted conflict and refugee crisisin the abovementioned countries in consultation with technical partners.The grant will be managed by IOM through an integrated grant management platform, based in Amman, Jordan as IOM will capitalize on its country missions in the region to oversee grant implementation on the grounds, including in hard to reach areas of Yemen and Syria.

title.narrative: Migration and its Impact on Cambodian Children and Families (MICCAF)

description.narrative: As outward migration in Cambodia continues to increase, its impact on the children and families of migrant workers inclusive of health, remains largely unknown. Concerns center on how separation from parents may affect children's nutritional, behavioral and psychological development and if furthermore the trends in migration have linkages to the increased placement of children in Residential Care Institutions (RCI) settings. In this regard a two phase project is proposed that aims to research the issue of left behind children and families in Cambodia. The first phase will focus on piloting and capacity building activities whilst phase two will consist of a community-based cross-sectional household survey among left-behind migrant worker families and qualitative study components to explore left-behind migrant children in child care institutions inclusive of children's perception of parental migration, child health status and parenting issues of migrant family households. The final outcome of the project will be to present the findings and recommendations via a country report to the Royal Government of Cambodia and Civil Society in Cambodia to assist with culturally appropriate interventions and national policy development.

title.narrative: 3MDG MNCH Technical Support to MHAA in Southern Part of Rakhine

description.narrative: The Three Millennium Development Goals - Maternal, New Born and Child Health (3MDG-MNCH) programme in the Rakhine State supports access to essential maternal and child health services. The programme has delivered significant gains in terms of health outputs and outcomes including the availability of trained voluntary health workers (community health workers and auxiliary midwives) across townships in Rakhine State, providing essential health services close to all communities. The community programmes are linked to township health staff and facilities providing an essential continuum of care. An emergency referral system links communities to life- saving emergency maternal and child care at township level. In line with the 3MDG funding support for Kyauk Phyu, Ann, and Taungoke to Myanmar Health Assistant Association (MHAA) in supporting the delivery of health services to the population in Southern Rakhine of the Township Health Department, MHAA has sub-contracted IOM to provide technical support to MHAA MNCH programming three locations in Southern Rakhine. IOM will work closely with MHAA project team in the intervention of 3MDG project activities including technical support and budget monitoring for Coordinated Township Health Plan (CTHP) of Township Health Department.

description.narrative: The proposed project is a continuation of the current PRM-funded project, which aims at contributing to the improvement of living conditions and health outcomes (including mental health and psychosocial well-being) of detainees, particularly migrant children between the ages 3 to 17 and women. The project will continue to offer children the opportunity to participate in daily educational and recreational activities designed to promote children's physical and mental development whilst ensuring the provision of supplementary food and hygiene kits, non-food items, and psychosocial support to detainee women and children and some men as permitted by immigration detention center (IDC) officials. In addition, the project will seek to expand support services made to available to long stay children and families released from the IDC on bail, noting their continued socio-economic and health-related vulnerabilities.

Focused on the prevention (of health-related issues), promotion (of migrant-friendly health services), and the provision (of migrant-friendly health care in concert with community based organizations), this programme will enhance access to healthcare services and improve healthcare options for project beneficiaries.

title.narrative: Strengthening Government Capacity in the Development and Implementation of a National Strategic Action Plan on Migration Health in Nepal

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to strengthen the capacity of the Government of Nepal (GoN) to address the health needs of inbound and outbound migrants using a multi-sectoral approach, particularly by reviewing, endorsing and implementing the National Strategic Action Plan(NSAP) on Migration Health. Specifically, over one year the project willsupport and advocate for the Ministry of Health review and endorse the NSAP on migration health, which when implemented will assist in comprehensively addressing health vulnerabilities of migrants and protecting their right to health through a multi-sectorial approach. It will also build the capacity of and support the GoN implement selected activities outlined in the NSAP. With this project 10M will respond to the recommendations from the Regional Dialogue on the Health Challenges for Asian Migrant Workers (July, 2010), the Dhaka Declaration (April, 2011) and the World Health Assembly Resolution 61 .17 (May, 2008) and assist Nepal in implementing these global and regional commitments and comprehensively addressing the multifaceted migration related health challenges.

title.narrative: Provide life-saving Primary Health Care Services and Provision of Rapid Response and Mental Health and Psychosocial Support for Vulnerable IDPs, Returnees and Affected Host Communities in Unity, Upper Nile and other sites across South Sudan

description.narrative: This project will provide life-saving emergency and essential primary health care (PHC) services through IOM static clinics, as well as mobileresponses through rapid response teams (RRT) missions. IOM will ensure abalance of both internally displaced persons (IDPs) and conflict-affected host community members prioritizing the greatest need. IOM will improve access to preventive and curative health services, covering all domains of emergency and PHC services. This includes routine immunization for children, early warning, alert and response system (EWARS)/ integrated disease surveillance and response (IDSR) and response to disease outbreaks, clinical management of rape, nutrition screening, comprehensive HIV/TB care and treatment, basic emergency obstetric and neonatal care services, integrated mental health and psychosocial support and health promotion. To ensure continuity of services and build national capacity for emergency response IOM will also provide training and mentorship for health personnel including fromthe Ministry of Health (MOH) and National NGOs.

title.narrative: Engaging diaspora to strengthen the health, flood prevention and agriculture sectors in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: This project aims to improve the knowledge, skills of the Sierra Leoneanhuman resources, and leverage the commitment of the Sierra Leonean diaspora to build human resources capacity in Sierra Leone. Due to the impact of recurrent infectious disease outbreaks and the recent devastating flooding, Sierra Leone needs technical support to upgrade its health, disaster prevention and IOM will collaborate with diaspora organizations, universities / training institutions and Health facilities in Sierra Leone to enhance skills and knowledge transfers to home country. Diaspora will deliver trainings through short-term physical deployment of diaspora members for infectious disease control training, maternal and child health training, subsistence farming / trading techniques and disaster prevention topics. Meanwhile, individualdiaspora experts with a long term intermittent plan to support the education and the health sector in Sierra Leone, will use Japanese E-Learning System to enhance the quality and the sustainability of in site training. This E-learning system called Knowledge Deliver, producedby Digital Knowledge Co., Ltd, will provide E-learning platform and the maintenance of the platform, meanwhile educational institutions and the diaspora experts will provide the administration of the system, the material to feed the platform and distance learning service.

title.narrative: Empowering Tawergha IDPs Through Community Based Protection and Mental Health and Psychosocial

description.narrative: In 2016, facilitated by the UNSMIL Human Rights Department, the local councils of Misurata and Tawergha, started an official reconciliation process with the aim of ending the displacement and addressing the reparations to the victims of both sides. The agreement was signed on August 31st, 2016. Since then, the pact was modified multiple times and parties failed on the implementation of the agreement. Up to date, Tawerghas are still living in very precarious makeshift sites across Libya and a recent attempt to return has been disrupted by militias fromMisurata in February 2018, creating secondary displacement settlements in the areas of Bani Walid and Sirt (Qararat ai-Qatef and Harawa).

title.narrative: Life-Saving Health Assistance to Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and Other Conflict-Affected Populations in Yemen

description.narrative: IOM plans to support 37 health facilities including Emergency Mobile Medical Teams (EMMT), fixed health centers and rural level hospitals in 17governorates of Yemen. An estimated over 400,000 IDPs and other conflict-affected Yemenis are expected to benefit from the health services provided by the supported health facilities. Through this project, IOM will improve access to the most vulnerable IDPs and other conflict affected people in the remote and hard to reach communities with a full package of primary health services including sexual and reproductive health care, as well as emergency secondary and tertiary level care through effective patient referral system. IOM will also increase synergies across this project with the MoPHP disease control programmes for TB, HIV/AIDS and malaria which are already supported by IOM Yemen through the Global Fund grant since 2017.

PMM will enable identification of priority locations vulnerable to the spread of communicable diseases and other health threats as a result of human mobility related to flooding and disease outbreaks, where public health resources need to be invested for response to such public health emergencies.

description.narrative: The project aims to support national efforts in responding to the on-going ebola epidemics (9th and 10th) in the Democratic Republic of Congo while strengthening national capacity to better prevent, detect and respond to public health emergencies in the future. The project is aligned with the National Response Plan (May 2018), World Health Organization's (WHO) Strategic Response Plan (May 2018) and the recommendations from the Joint External Evaluation (JEE) on the implementation of the International Health Regulations (IHR) conducted in March 2018. The project will focus on strengthening surveillance at point of entries and at important congregation points, cross border coordination and technical and operational support for contingency planning specifically as it relates to capacity building of International Health Regulations (2005) core capacities.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Technical Capacities of the Government of Belize Towards Developing a National Migration and Development Policy

description.narrative: Migration represents a growing challenge in Belize due to the lack of comprehensive related data and consequently effective migration-related policies. Therefore, this project has the overall objective of supporting evidence-based policy making in Belize and will include support to mainstreaming migration data into migration and related policymaking and planning processes. During the first stage of this process two key documents will be produced, a household survey of the migrant population living in Belize and a desk review on the existing regulations and legislations related to migration issues. During the second phase, I0M will support and monitor the consultation processes with the government counterparts. Civil society, academic instructions, diaspora communities and migrant organizations, leading to the elaboration of a framework and concrete action plan to build the foundation towards the development of a migration and development policy.

title.narrative: Migration Management Framework (MMF): Capacity Building to Support Evidence-Based Migration Management

description.narrative: In 2015, IOM and the Economist Intelligence Unit developed the MigrationGovernance Indicators (MGI). The main purpose of the MGI is to help governments, upon request, take stock of the migration policies and strategies they have in place, to identify good practices as well as areas in need of further development. This can be done at regular intervals to ensure that government structures are adapted to the challenges and opportunities stemming from new migration trends. This tool builds upon the notion that national governments have complete sovereignty over their migration policies. The MGI’s ultimate objective is to help governments make progress on their migration management priorities, through the use of the Migration Governance Indicators (MGI), and by doing so contributing to increasing safe, orderly and regular migration practices. This project is anchored in the understanding that migration policies can differ widely according to regional, national, and local conditions and priorities. Therefore this project does not aim at ranking or comparing countries based on their respective migration management systems, nor does it propose a one-size fits all approach to migration management. In this regard, the MGI is a voluntary, flexible, context-specific and non-prescriptive tool. This project envisages four main components implemented over the course of one year: (1) Country selection and confirmation of interest; (2) Data collection and analysis; (3) Inter-ministerial consultations; and (4) Publication of the results.

title.narrative: Zambia Migration Profile: Supporting Evidence-Based Migration-Related Policymaking and Planning in Zambia – Phase II

description.narrative: The Government of the Republic of Zambia (GRZ) has requested the assistance of the International Organization for Migration (IOM) to strengthen its capacity to collect, analyse and utilize migration data, and ultimately to prepare a Migration Profile. Improving migration management at a national level has been identified as a priority for theGRZ. Data, including migration data, is required as part of this process, including the ongoing monitoring and evaluation of actions under the plan. IOM Zambia has been providing support to GRZ to have access to and utilize an increased level of reliable data on migration through a current and ongoing12-month IDF project: Migration Profiles Phase I. Phase I is intended to provide a foundation for the developmentof a full migration profile and to feed into policy making and planning processes through the development of a migration data assessment, which will highlight data ability, data gaps and recommendations. Following anew request from the Government of Zambia in 2017, IOM intends to carry out a follow-up project, ultimately to develop a full migration profile under Phase II of the project. Phase II would support the Central Statistics Office and key line ministries (in particular the Ministry ofHome Affairs and the Ministry of Labour) with strengthened systems to collect, analyse and utilize migration related data.

title.narrative: Honduras Migration Profile: Supporting Evidence-Based Migration-Related Policymaking and Planning

description.narrative: The Government of the Republic of Honduras has requested the assistance of the International Organization for Migration (IOM) to strengthen its capacity to collect, analyse and utilize migration data, and ultimately to prepare a Migration Profile. Improving migration management at a national level has been identified as a priority for the Government of Honduras. This comes at a time when migration dynamics in the country and the region have become complex; however, at present in Honduras there is a severe lack of reliable migration data and analysis on which to base policy formulation and planning. The proposed project intends to strengthen the coordination mechanisms amongst key line ministries. This will enhance their capacities on migration-related issues and feed policy planning and making processes through the development of a migration profile, highlighting data ability, gaps and recommendations.

title.narrative: Assessing Potential Changes in the Migration Patterns of Cambodian Migrants and their Impacts on Thailand and Cambodia

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to contribute towards the Governments of Thailand and Cambodia developing transparent and rights-based migration policies and programmes which maximize positive contributions of migration to the economies and societies of both countries. In this context, an assessment will be undertaken to enhance the evidence base regarding the situation of Cambodian migrants in Thailand, the effects of migration on poverty reduction in Cambodia, and potential changes in migration patterns of Cambodian migrants to Thailand in the future. The study will encompass quantitative and qualitative interviews with Cambodian migrants in Thailand, as well as government officials, employers, and civil society organizations. A report will be drafted based upon the findings of the assessment, and a wide range of stakeholders- governmental and non-governmental - will be invited to actively participate in a consultative workshop, at which the findings of the assessment will be presented. The report will encompass tailored recommendations for governmental authorities in both Cambodia and Thailand as well as development actors, and endorsement will be sought by the relevant line ministries of both countries.

title.narrative: A Research Paper on Exploring the Links Between Enhancing Regular Pathways and Irregular Migration

description.narrative: A research paper will analyse new avenues for governing regular migration pathways through enhanced flexibility, streamlined administrative processes that take the motivation and temptation out of prospective irregular migrants. To maximize the paper's utility during the intergovernmental negotiations, it will have a strong focus on policy analysis and provide a succinct but substantive account of various strategies aimed at expanding regular pathways while reducing irregular migration incentives.

title.narrative: Nepal Migration Profile: Promoting Strategic and Evidence Based Policy Making

description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to promote and support evidence-based policy making and to call attention to the benefits of mainstreaming migration profile. In order to enhance coordination among relevant stakeholders and ensure the ownership, the project will establish an inter-ministerial working group, and the migration profile will be prepared in full consultation with the working group members. Additionally, the project will widely disseminate the findings of the migration profile and train policy makers and practitioners on how to collect, analyze and utilize migration data for policy making development.

title.narrative: Botswana Migration Profile: Supporting Evidence-Based Migration-Related Policymaking and Planning in Botswana

description.narrative: The overall objective of the project is to contribute to evidence-based policy making and development planning in Botswana, through improved data collection, analysis and dissemination. The project will support the assessment of data collection tools and systems in identified key ministries and institutions, and information sharing between different stakeholders through capacity building interventions. An inter-ministerial and multi-disciplinary Technical Working Group (TWG) will be established and trained to provide technical guidance and oversight during the project implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: Third Floor, Barclays House ;Plot 8842; Khama Crescent, Gaborone, Botswana

title.narrative: Migration Profile: Timor-Leste

description.narrative: The objective of the proposed project is to contribute to good migrationgovernance that enhances national programming, planning and policymakingin Timor-Leste. The development of a migration profile will increase awareness of migration information and data as a national resource, and its potential to be effectively utilized and mainstreamed for national actions in the area of migration, mobility and development. The migration profile will contribute to a better understanding of current internal and international migration trends through the collection and analysis of age- and gender-disaggregated migration data, and improve the knowledgebase of how population mobility impacts social and economicdynamics. The project's main outcome is 'stakeholders strengthen national programming, planning and policymaking through improved collection and management of migration information and data'. The migration profile will adequately incorporate various dimensions of migration to provide an overview addressing trends and key features, the impact of migration, labour migration and economic development, international and regional cooperation, and identify key findings, policy implications and recommendations. Throughout this process, capacity building activities will be conducted with key government actors and other relevant stakeholders involved in migration governance to ensure they have the knowledge and skills to utilize the migration profile’s findings and recommendations.

mailing-address.narrative: UN House, Building 09 Caicoli Street, Dili, Timor-Leste

title.narrative: Global migration data portal (phase III)

description.narrative: One of the most apparent shortfalls in the current migration data space until recently was the absence of a comprehensive, one-stop-shop for migration information and data, both in the form of timely textual analysis, including the strengths and weaknesses of the data sources, and, in particular, for data access and analysis purposes. Many public policy communities, over the years, have suffered from a diffuse and confusing approach to information. At the same time some areas account for very advanced information. Economic development data is available, for example, on dozens of websites, as is information on public health issues. Since the launch of the Global Migration Data Portal, from herein after referred to as the Portal, in December 2017, the Portal has pursued a long-term strategy to become the primary point of departure for all stakeholders interested in migration data and to become an exchange platform for the international community of migration experts and agencies developed by IOM's Global Migration Data Analysis Centre, in partnership with key international experts and UN agencies, the portal strives to meet three goals: it must be useful, comprehensive andtimely. In this context, 'useful' means that the content is valuable to users, and that they will want to come back frequently for updates. 'Comprehensive' means that the Portal covers the widest range of countries and migration topics possible. This means that the Portal is not limited, as are other migration data-related websites, to a certain region or topic. Timely' means that the Portal uploads new migration data indicators as they are released, publishes blogs that cover emerging topics and videos with migration experts to explain ongoing migration topics in Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America. In order to become a global reference point on migration data, the Portal must be expanded.

mailing-address.narrative: Charlottenstraße 68, Berlin D-10117, Germany

title.narrative: Migration Profile in Fiji: Building the Capacity for Evidence-Based Policy

description.narrative: As a regional hub in the Pacific, Fiji is considered as an origin, transit and destination country in the context of international migration. Migration dynamics are becoming increasingly complex with growing impacts of both slow-onset and rapid-onset climate change. Efforts in addressing intersecting issues such as trafficking in persons(TIP) and a renewed focus on promoting sustainable labour mobility in the country through seasonal worker programmes with Australia and New Zealand highlight that well-managed migration is a priority for the Government of Fiji.

title.narrative: World Migration Report 2020

description.narrative: This project contributes to the publication, in late 2019, of the next edition of the World Migration Report, as the reference report on migration for policymakers, practitioners, and researchers. The World Migration Report aims to leverage IOM's programmatic knowledge and experience and the skills and expertise of academic and applied researchers from around the world. The World Migration Report 2020 will follow the two-part structure initiated by the previous edition, the World Migration Report 2018, which consists of: 1) key information on migration and migrants, including migration- related information and statistics updated from report to report; and 2) balanced, evidence-based analysis of complex and emerging migration issues, with afocus on new topics for each report.
