title.narrative: Facilitating Refugee Resettlement to Lithuania

description.narrative: This project aims to provide comprehensive resettlement services to those refugees identified by the Government of Lithuania for resettlement to Lithuania in 2016 and 2017. Resettlement will take placefrom Turkey. IOM Turkey will provide logistical support to the refugees as follows: facilitation of permits for internal travel, transportation of refugees from place of residence to interview, accommodation, catering, and interpretation services. Once the selection process is concluded by the Migration department under the Ministry of the Interior(MD), in coordination with UNHCR, IOM Turkey will provide a pre-departure orientation session and a pre-embarkation session to support smooth travel from Turkey to Lithuania and explain the process of travelling as well as the procedures on flight. IOM Turkey will also conduct pre-departure health assessments. 24-48h before departure, refugees will go through a pre-departure fit-to-travel/pre-embarkation check (FTT/PEC) (also facilitated by IOM Turkey).IOM Turkey is responsible for the movement management and pre-departure travel arrangements for the final stage of departure: tickets to domestic and to final destination, transportation to embarkation airports, provision of escorts where deemed necessary, and departure assistance for selectedrefugees. The integration process will involve NGOs in Lithuania who will accompany and guide refugees through their integration during the post-arrival Lithuania phase.

title.narrative: Resettlement Activities for Refugees in Lebanon

description.narrative: This resettlement project aims to find long term durable solution for refugees, mainly focusing on those who remain vulnerable (as determined by the UNHCR) in the first country of asylum, Lebanon. This project has two components to assist in the selection process for resettlement of Syrian refugees presently in Lebanon to a third country. The first project objective is to provide logistical support and assistance to the interview selection missions conducted by the Norwegian Government or other governments for an estimated 900 refugees who will be interviewed as part of the selection process for resettlement to Norway or other countries. Under the second component of the project IOM will provide comprehensive medical assessments of refugees being considered for resettlement on medical grounds, up to a total of 300 Syrian refugees. IOM medical personnel will complete the Medical Assessment Forms (MAFs) for 300 refugees. In addition, up to 100 Quick Medical Checks will be administered by IOM medical personnel.

title.narrative: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland’s Resettlement Programmes

description.narrative: In response to the continuing crisis in Syria and the influx of Syrian refugees as well as other refugees to neighbouring countries, the UK Government announced in September 2015, its commitment to providing humanitarian protection through the resettlement of 20,000 vulnerable refugees from the MENA region that meet one of UNHCR’s seven vulnerability criteria under the Vulnerable Persons Resettlement Scheme (VPR) until the year 2020. In light of the above, the UK has committed to accepting 4,800 persons from Egypt (500), Iraq (400), Lebanon (1,800), Jordan (1,600) and Turkey (500), under the VPR scheme. This project is intended to provide comprehensive resettlement support to those refugees identified by UNHCR and accepted by the UK Government for resettlement to the UK in 2018/2019.

title.narrative: Vulnerable Children Resettlement Scheme

description.narrative: Given the continuing conflict in the MENA region and the particular vulnerabilities of refugee children, the UK Government announced in April 2016 the launch of the Vulnerable Children’s Resettlement Scheme (VCRS). The scheme is aimed at refugee children and adolescents at risk, regardless of nationality, from within the region, (Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey), who may be unaccompanied or accompanied by family members, and who are deemed to be in need of humanitarian protection. In light of the above, the UK has committed to accepting 1,200 persons from Egypt (400), Iraq (100), Jordan (200), Lebanon (300) and Turkey (200), under the VCRS between April 2018 and March 2019 and overall 3,000 to 2020. This project is intended to provide comprehensive resettlement support to those refugees identified by UNHCR and accepted by the UK Government for resettlement to the UK in 2018/2019.

description.narrative: The project aims to facilitate the resettlement to the UK of vulnerable refugees of various nationalities. In order to do so, IOM aims to provide comprehensive resettlement support to 589 refugees identified by UNHCR and accepted by the UK Government for resettlement from the following country locations: Burundi (150), Iraq (50), Kenya (200), Sudan (73) and Syria (75) under the programme. An additional 41 beneficiaries from Egypt will also be assisted by IOM with pre-departure orientation and movement assistance. Those selected to resettle in the United Kingdom as part of the Gateway Resettlement Programme are living in rural or urban informal settlements or refugee camps in host countries worldwide and are registered with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).

In particular, the IOM is proposing to develop capacity and offer services in a number of location globally on Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada's (IRCC) behalf. This new agreement will be and innovative project which will give the IOM the ability to process clients in a number of locations globally without pre-determined target numbers, where IRCC has determined assistance is required. title.narrative: Transfer of Unaccompanied Asylum-Seeking Children from France, Greece and Italy to the United Kingdom

description.narrative: Throughout this project, IOM aims to support the transfer of a total of 236 unaccompanied and separated children (UASC) from Europe to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (UK). The UK authorities, in coordination with the French, Greek and Italian authorities will identify 90 UASC in France, 96 UASC in Greece and 50 UASC in Italy due for transfer under this project. Subsequent to the final selection of the UASC, IOM France, Greece and Italy in coordination with IOM UK, as managing mission, will develop key safeguards and appropriate mechanisms to relocate each UASC. IOM will use its experience and technical skills to ensure that safeguards for vulnerable unaccompanied children, based on international and national standards, are utilised throughout the process in addition to providing a continuum of care.

title.narrative: Providing Refugee Resettlement Assistance to the Government of Germany

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to assist the German Government, represented by the German Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF), with the resettlement of up to 300 of the most vulnerable refugees (mainly from Eritrea and Somalia), who were evacuated by UNHCR from Libya to Niger. After BAMF has completed the selection of the beneficiaries IOM will provide comprehensive refugee resettlement support consisting of logistical arrangements for the selection mission and for visa processing, pre-departure health assessment (PDHA), pre-departure orientation (PDO) and movement and travel assistance from Niamey to Germany.

title.narrative: Strengthening international protection, reception and integration of refugees in Argentina

description.narrative: This project aims to improve the institutional capacity of Argentine State in managing the reception and integration mechanisms for beneficiaries of the Special Program for the Issuance of Humanitarian Visas for People affected by the conflict in the Arab Republic of Syria or, in short, the Syria Program, which enables Argentine nationals, permanent resident, organizations and institutions in Argentina to sponsor people who are fleeing the Syrian conflict and wish to settle in Argentina. The project will promote capacity building for government and civil society actors to improve reception condition for resettled Syrian in Argentina, and strengthen integration schemes at national and local levels, in coordination with beneficiaries and the host communities, to achieve an effective local integration and guarantee access to durable solutions in the country.

title.narrative: Colombia: Strengthening the Implementation of the Victim Assistance and Reparation Policy within the Framework of the Final Agreement for the Termination of the Conflict in the Targeted Territories.

description.narrative: The purpose of the project is to contribute to the adjustment of strategies that contribute to strengthening and articulating the implementation of the Comprehensive Care and Reparation Policy for Victims and the Final Agreement for the termination of the conflict in the targeted territories between the parties in Colombia. This process will be carried out through:1. Strengthen the institutional capacities of the Unit to make the adjustments and implementation of territorial intervention actions to harmonize planning and execution instruments required by public policy in the framework of post-conflict and peace building; 2. Strengthen institutional response strategies, administrative and judicial, in the face of progress in relation to compliance with orders of the Constitutional Court and based on legal guidelines, articulation with the mission information provided by the technical areas and that the advances related to the implementation of public policy are supported; 3. Strengthen the communication scheme of the Unit with and for the victims, their organizations, the defenders organizations and other stakeholders, improving the framework of the Public Policy of Victims through the construction of the balance and the proposal on the prospective of the public policy of victims.

The intervention will prioritize the distribution of standard life-saving items to the most vulnerable households that did not receive NFI assistance since their arrival in the camp and the most vulnerable among the new arrivals. In Jed’ah camp, the presence of IOM in the camp as a Camp Coordinator & Camp Management (CCCM) actor and the close cooperation with the camp management will ensure a timely and effective NFI response.

title.narrative: Emergency Shelter, NFI Kits And Camp Coordination And Camp Management (CCCM) Support for Populations Affected by the Conflict in Yemen

description.narrative: This action aims at targeting Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) Households in the most affected areas of Yemen with needed Shelter emergency materials and Non-Food Items (NFIs). Both in-kind and cash modalities will be utilized to support IDPs with the NFI and Shelter assistance. In addition to the NFI and Shelter support, IOM will support IDPs with cash for rent assistance to provide essential shelter support for extremely vulnerable families. Furthermore, IOM will implement Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) activities aiming at raising up the levels of coordination, appropriateness, effectiveness, and accountability of the humanitarian response by ensuring regular participatory assessments and setting up two-way communication channels between displaced communities, host communities, humanitarian actors, and government/ de-facto authorities.

Through the proposed project, the Shelter and NFI sector will coordinate initial efforts on distribution of basic survival items through a standardized kit which comprises: temporary shelter (tarpaulins and plastic sheeting) and water jerrycans, buckets, sleeping mats, blankets, cooking utensils, mosquito nets etc. Additional items will be added on the kit based on the specific needs of the gender groups, particularly sanitary cloths for women and girls of reproductive age.

description.narrative: Since 2014, the conflict in eastern Ukraine has continued to generate urgent humanitarian needs of the affected population. As a result of the absence of a functioning market and the banking system in the non-government-controlled areas (NGCA), as well as the situation of the chronically depressed economy, the de facto administration has struggled to provide essential social services and assistance to those within its constituency. Through this project, IOM aims to provide lifesaving winterization and hygiene non-food items to the most vulnerable individuals in conflict-affected communities in Donetsk and Luhansk NGCA.

title.narrative: Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Items for Flood Affected Internally Displaced Persons

description.narrative: Flood affected areas of Ethiopia require immediate life-saving interventions for vulnerable households, particularly the 19,000 displaced households who have lost most of their physical possessions. The project aims to directly support flood-affected populations in their current area of displacement in the country and to enable safe and rapid return to areas of origin (Shelter (ES)/Non-Food Items (NFI)) thus alleviating conditions in evacuation sites. Flood-affected populations in their area of origin will also be assisted to ‘build back better’ through immediate repair and rehabilitation and transitional shelter construction alongside flood water recession when affected people are expected to return – meeting their immediate Shelter needs and also mitigating the impact of future flooding.

title.narrative: Promoting Better Shelter and Settlements Practices

description.narrative: Shelter Projects is a collection done at the global cluster level of global case studies that focuses on meritorious practices in responding to shelter needs during emergencies. These studies include common issues emerging in the wake of crisis situations; different approaches to addressing shelter needs; and lessons learned from both good practices and challenges encountered. It is intended that collecting case studies and learnings from shelter programmes will provide the basis to improve the global, regional, national and local capacities to address future post-crisis emergency/recovery shelter issues. Through this project, IOM aims to 1) compile new case studies of shelter and settlements responses; 2) ensure effective dissemination, maximising relevant readership and ensuring longer term engagement in the Shelter Projects publication through increased participation in the content; and 3) promote the case studies as a learning tool to improve shelter and settlements operations and staff capacity at country and regional level, as well as to develop context-specific learnings through collective review of the case studies.

To ensure a comprehensive response, IOM will includesupport directly to the Shelter Cluster that it co-leads, particularly for coordination and Information Management through the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in order to better track and report on the people in evacuation centres and their return and/or relocation process as wellas the basic needs for services and assistance at the most affected villages as they recover (Shelter activities).

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM will provide shelter support to the most vulnerable households in the Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR), with a specific focus on Benguet, and families seeking to return to damaged houses across Cagayan Valley after the typhoon Ompong in the Philippines. Interventions in the targeted areas will focus on the municipality of Itogon, where about 400 households from barangays Ucab and Loacan remain displaced. To ensure that the most appropriate shelter solution is provided to the wider affected populations across CAR and Cagayan Valley this intervention will make available 4 differentshelter packages adapted to address the most urgent shelter needs identified: Transitional Shelter, Shelter Repair Kits, Emergency ShelterKits, and Cash Grants for those with staying with host families.

description.narrative: This project will provide support to those who have been displaced to care centres as well as communities who have been significantly affectedbut have remained in their home after the earthquake that hit the highlands of Papua New Guinea on 26 February 2018. In particular, this project will provide the affected population with 400 community reconstruction kits with basic carpenter tools Southern Highlands Province and Hela Province. The total shelter response is then expected to reach 60% of households affected by the earthquake. Pending registration verification, this may include supplies for people returning to their homes from care centres, or those displaced within their own community.
